name: Elevator Operator: Up and down, the on-screen gift of elevators
description: Inspired by Courtney Barnett playing an elevator operator in her hit song of the same name, we look at how they're used on-screen for comedy, drama and suspense, with the small, confined boxes forcing characters to physically confront each other.

key_work.title: Elevator Operator – Courtney Barnett
key_work.brief_description: Courtney Barnett’s ‘Elevator Operator’ (2016) leans hard into theatrical inspirations like the work of Wes Anderson and features familiar screen faces like Madgda Szubanski, Sleater-Kinney, Tim Rogers, Paul Kelly and Michael Leunig as they travel through the elevator in Melbourne’s Nicholas Building.

end.title: North by northwest
end.brief_description: Alfred Hitchcock nominated this literal cliff hanger as the film that most epitomised the elements of his years of making thrillers. Roger Thornhill (Cary Grant) is a smug but successful Madison Avenue advertising executive who is plunged into the world of espionage when he his mistaken for mythical agent George Kaplan who US intelligence has created to flush out spies. Matters are further complicated when he meets Eve Kendall (Eva Saint-Marie) who further jeopardises his life while being romantically involved with him. Kidnapped by spies, Thornhill escapes but is then accused of killing a UN diplomat. He is pursued by both spies and the police and desperately flees across country, buzzed by a crop duster plane in one of the films most memorable scenes. His meeting with arch spy James Mason on the Mount Rushmore monument provides the heart-stopping climax as the pair fight it out on the giant sculptures of former US presidents.

constellations_other.name: Elevator Operator: Up and down, the on-screen gift of elevators
constellations_other.description: Inspired by Courtney Barnett playing an elevator operator in her hit song of the same name, we look at how they're used on-screen for comedy, drama and suspense, with the small, confined boxes forcing characters to physically confront each other.

links.description: Alfred Hitchcock injects comedy into the suspenseful thriller North by North West when Roger Thornhill finds himself in an elevator with his mother, and the two men who are trying to kill him.

start.title: North by northwest
start.brief_description: Alfred Hitchcock nominated this literal cliff hanger as the film that most epitomised the elements of his years of making thrillers. Roger Thornhill (Cary Grant) is a smug but successful Madison Avenue advertising executive who is plunged into the world of espionage when he his mistaken for mythical agent George Kaplan who US intelligence has created to flush out spies. Matters are further complicated when he meets Eve Kendall (Eva Saint-Marie) who further jeopardises his life while being romantically involved with him. Kidnapped by spies, Thornhill escapes but is then accused of killing a UN diplomat. He is pursued by both spies and the police and desperately flees across country, buzzed by a crop duster plane in one of the films most memorable scenes. His meeting with arch spy James Mason on the Mount Rushmore monument provides the heart-stopping climax as the pair fight it out on the giant sculptures of former US presidents.

end.title: Elevator Action
end.brief_description:
Elevator Action (エレベーターアクション Erebētā Akushon) is a 1983 arcade game by Taito. It debuted during the “Golden Age of Arcade Games”. Innovative in gameplay, the game was very popular for many years.

In the game, the player assumes the role of a spy who infiltrates a building filled with elevators. He must collect secret documents from the building and traverse the 30 floors of the building using an increasingly complex series of elevators. The player is pursued by enemy agents who appear from behind closed doors. These agents must be dealt with via force or evasion. Successful completion of a level involves collecting all the secret documents and traversing the building from top to bottom. In the lower floors of the building, the elevator systems are so complex that some puzzle-solving skills are needed.

The game was available as a standard upright cabinet The controls consist of a 4-way joystick and two buttons, one for “shoot” and the other for jumping and kicking. The maximum number of players is two, alternating turns. The graphics are extremely simple, 2D color graphics and in-game music was composed by musician Yoshio Imamura. The game was followed by a sequel, Elevator Action II (also known as Elevator Action Returns).

links.description: The 1983 action platform arcade game pits players against a 30-story building full of enemy spies. Starting on the roof, players use elevators to make their escape, collecting secret documents and fighting foes.

start.title: The Grand Budapest Hotel
start.creator_credit: Jeremy Dawson, Scott Rudin, Steven M. Rales and Wes Anderson
start.headline_credit: Germany and United States of America, 2014

video_links.name: THE GRAND BUDAPEST HOTEL - Official Wolrdwide Trailer HD

start.brief_description: The Grand Budapest Hotel tells of a legendary concierge at a famous European hotel between the wars and his friendship with a young employee who becomes his trusted protégé.

constellations_other.name: Directions of storytelling
constellations_other.description: Panoramic slides gave magic lanternists the ability to progress narratives by adjusting slides left or right. This movement is emblematic of a panning shot where the camera follows the action the natural way your head moves.

end.title: Die Hard
end.creator_credit: John McTiernan, Marilyn Vance, Beau Marks, Joel Silver, Lawrence Gordon, 20th Century Fox, Gordon Company, Silver Pictures, Jackson De Govia, Jeb Stuart, Steven E. de Souza and Matthew Yuricich
end.brief_description: NYPD cop John McClane’s plan to reconcile with his estranged wife is thrown for a serious loop when, minutes after he arrives at her office, the entire building is overtaken by a group of terrorists. With little help from the LAPD, wisecracking McClane sets out to single-handedly rescue the hostages and bring the bad guys down.

constellations_other.name: Elevator Operator: Up and down, the on-screen gift of elevators
constellations_other.description: Inspired by Courtney Barnett playing an elevator operator in her hit song of the same name, we look at how they're used on-screen for comedy, drama and suspense, with the small, confined boxes forcing characters to physically confront each other.

links.description: John McClane (Bruce Willis) makes a perilous drop down an elevator shaft in his attempt to traverse the Nakatomi building undetected by terrorists. The action sequence is heightened by the real fall of Willis’ stunt double which was edited into the finished scene.

links.description: Elevators, dumbwaiters and funiculars feature prominently in Wes Anderson’s Grand Budapest Hotel. The lavish red elevator perfectly frames hotel staff who appear in purple velvet uniforms. While the wealthy Madam D also in red seems to disappear into the backdrop.

end.title: Bombshell
end.creator_credit: Jay Roach, Charlize Theron, Colleen Atwood, Aaron L. Gilbert, A.J. Dix, Beth Kono, Charles Randolph, Margaret Riley, Michelle Graham, Robert Graf, Annapurna Pictures, Bron Studios, Creative Wealth Media Finance, Denver and Delilah Productions, Endeavor Content, Lighthouse Management + Media, Lionsgate, Mark Ricker and Norie Varga
end.headline_credit: Canada and United States of America, 2019
end.brief_description: Bombshell is a revealing look inside the most powerful and controversial media empire of all time; and the explosive story of the women who brought down the infamous man who created it.

constellations_other.name: Elevator Operator: Up and down, the on-screen gift of elevators
constellations_other.description: Inspired by Courtney Barnett playing an elevator operator in her hit song of the same name, we look at how they're used on-screen for comedy, drama and suspense, with the small, confined boxes forcing characters to physically confront each other.

links.description: While no dialogue is spoken the silence of the elevator scene in Bombshell speaks volumes. Tightly confined, it’s the only time in which Kayla, Megyn and Gretchen, who have all experienced harassment, appear together. While physically close they are emotionally distanced, all feeling powerless.

links.description: Examining racism and historic prejudice, in ‘Who’s Afraid of the Big Black Man’, Dre has a predicament: help a toddler alone in an elevator or back away so that he’s not accused of a dark ulterior motive.
